name: Billing plan fee disclosure and prohibited fees
description: Checks that billing and payment plan documents clearly disclose all non-premium fees and do not include prohibited banking or service fees for bail bond business.
prompt:
You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. This check applies mainly to billing plans, payment plan descriptions, declarations pages, or other documents that describe how premiums are billed and what non-premium charges may apply.

Requirement:

1. If a document describes any fee that is separate from the base premium (for example installment fees, billing plan fees, service fees, late fees, returned-check/nsf fees, electronic payment fees, or similar charges), the document must:
- Give the fee a plain-language name;
- State either a fixed dollar amount or a specific formula that allows the fee to be calculated;
- Explain exactly what event triggers the fee (for example use of an installment plan, a missed payment, or a returned check); and
- State whether the fee is charged per installment, per occurrence, or per policy term.

2. The document may not hide fees behind vague phrases such as "other fees may apply", "service charge", or "miscellaneous fee" without also providing the concrete amount or formula and trigger for each such fee.

3. If the document appears to describe bail bond business (for example, it repeatedly refers to bail bonds, defendants, or bond forfeiture), it must not impose separate "banking fees" for returned checks or stop payments, nor other service-related fees such as after-hours or travel fees, because n.j.a.c. 11:17b-3.2(d) prohibits bail bond agencies from charging those specific fees.

The filing passes this check only if every billing- or payment-related document that mentions non-premium charges meets the disclosure requirements in (1) and (2), and no bail bond document imposes the prohibited fees in (3). If you find any fee that is unclear, incompletely described, or clearly prohibited, treat this check as failed and identify the problematic language.

name: Plain language and readability compliance
description: Checks that consumer-facing forms comply with new jersey plain language and readability requirements and that an appropriate affidavit of compliance is included.
prompt:
You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. This check focuses on compliance with new jersey's plain language act (n.j.s.a. 56:12-1 et seq.) and the insurance readability rules (n.j.a.c. 11:2-18) for consumer insurance forms.

Treat as "consumer-facing" any policy, endorsement, application, billing plan, or notice that is intended to be read and signed or relied on by an individual insured or small business policyholder, rather than only by regulators or internal staff.

Requirements:

1. Affidavit / certificate of compliance:
- There should be at least one attached affidavit or certificate of compliance stating that the contract and related writings comply with the plain language law (n.j.s.a. 56:12-1 et seq.) and n.j.a.c. 11:2-18, and stating the flesch reading ease test score (or equivalent) for the form(s).
- That affidavit should also say that the forms are printed in at least the minimum type size required by the readability rules (typically at least 10-point type for policies and at least 8-point type for certain applications), or equivalent wording.
- For each consumer-facing form in the filing, its form number should appear somewhere in that affidavit or in an attached list that the affidavit explicitly covers.

2. Plain language of the forms themselves:
- Consumer-facing forms should use straightforward, everyday language, with reasonably short sentences and paragraphs, and should avoid long blocks of all-capital text, dense cross-references, and unnecessary legal jargon.
- Key obligations, fees, and time periods should be stated directly and unambiguously, not hidden in complex subordinate clauses or double negatives.
- Headings, section titles, and numbering should help the reader navigate the document, and important concepts such as fees, cancellations, and coverage limitations should be easy to locate.

The filing passes this check only if (a) there is a clear plain-language/readability affidavit that covers the consumer-facing forms in the filing, and (b) on a reasonable reading, those forms themselves appear simple, clear, understandable, and easily readable in line with the plain language act and n.j.a.c. 11:2-18. If either the affidavit coverage or the readability of the forms is clearly deficient, treat this check as failed and describe what is missing.

name: File identity block
description: Checks that each attached file clearly identifies itself and the company.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: each file that is a narrative document, policy form, endorsement, rate manual, or actuarial memorandum must have an identity block near the beginning that clearly states all of the following: (1) the full legal name of the insurance company or filing entity; (2) a clear document title that describes what the file is (for example 'commercial auto rate manual', 'policy form', 'actuarial memorandum', 'cover letter'); and (3) some explicit document identifier such as a form number, file number, or version label. The file passes this check only if all three elements are present and readable in that file. If any of the three elements is missing, incomplete, or only implied, the file fails this check.

name: No conflicting state or regulator references
description: Checks that files do not incorrectly refer to another state or regulator as controlling.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: no attached file may contain language that clearly treats a state other than new jersey, or a non–new jersey insurance regulator, as the primary jurisdiction for the policy, rates, or rules being filed. The file fails this check if it includes statements such as 'this policy is governed by the laws of [other state]', 'filed with the [other state] department of insurance', or similar language that obviously points to a different state as the controlling jurisdiction. References to federal law, generic phrases like 'applicable state law', or historical examples are acceptable. The file passes this check only if it does not contain any such conflicting out-of-state jurisdiction or regulator references.

name: Company name consistency within file
description: Checks that each file uses one consistent company name and does not mix unrelated company names.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: within any single file, references to the insurance company must be consistent. The file passes this check if: (1) the same company legal name is used throughout, or a clearly indicated group name and company name pair is used in a consistent way; and (2) there are no unexplained switches to a different company name that looks like an entirely different legal entity. If the file uses two or more different company names with no explanation (for example, it starts with one company name in the header and later refers to a completely different company as the insurer), the file fails this check.

name: Form or document number and revision date
description: Checks that policy forms, endorsements, and similar controlled documents show a clear document number and revision date.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: every file that is a policy form, endorsement, application, notice, or other controlled form must display both (1) a form or document number and (2) a clear edition or revision date. These items should appear near the top or bottom of the first page and should look like a deliberate control label (for example, 'form ca-1234 (ed. 06 20)'). The file passes this check only if it has both a recognizable form or document number and an edition or revision date. If one or both are missing, illegible, or only implied, the file fails this check. For files that are clearly not forms (for example pure exhibits, spreadsheets, or technical appendices), this check may be treated as not applicable rather than failed.

name: Page numbering and continuity
description: Checks that multi-page files have clear page numbering and no obvious gaps.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: any file that has more than one page must use page numbering that makes the sequence clear. The file passes this check if: (1) each page shows a page number (for example 'page 3 of 10' or 'page 3'); and (2) the sequence is continuous without missing or repeated page numbers that suggest pages are missing or out of order. If a multi-page file has no page numbers, or if the page numbers clearly skip or repeat in a way that indicates missing content (for example jumping from page 3 to page 5 of 6), the file fails this check. Single-page files automatically pass this check.

name: No draft or editing markers
description: Checks that files do not contain track changes, editor comments, or obvious drafting placeholders.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: attached files must appear as clean, final documents, not drafts. The file fails this check if it contains any of the following: (1) visible track changes markup such as strikeouts, underlines, or colored insertions with revision balloons; (2) editor comment bubbles or inline comments like 'comment:' or 'tk'; (3) obvious drafting notes such as 'insert text here', 'example only', 'lorem ipsum', '[state name]', or '[company name]' that are not filled in; or (4) repeated 'draft' labels that indicate the document is not final. Normal fillable fields for insured-specific data (names, addresses, limits, premium amounts, and similar information) are acceptable and do not cause failure. The file passes this check only if none of the draft or editing markers listed above are present.

name: Internal cross-reference integrity
description: Checks that references within each file (and to other files) point to real sections, forms, or exhibits.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: cross-references in the files must be logically valid. For each file, check that: (1) references to sections or paragraphs within that file (for example 'see section iv', 'see paragraph 3.b') actually correspond to sections or paragraphs that exist and contain content; and (2) references to other forms, endorsements, schedules, or exhibits (by number or title) match at least one attached file in the overall document set. The filing passes this check only if you do not find any obvious broken references, such as 'see section vi' when no section vi exists, or references to forms or exhibits that cannot be matched to any attached file. If you find any clearly broken or impossible cross-reference, treat this check as failed and identify the problematic reference.

name: Definitions and usage consistency
description: Checks that defined terms within a file are clearly introduced and used consistently.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: any file that relies on defined terms (for example capitalized words like 'insured', 'policy period', 'covered auto') must introduce those terms clearly and then use them consistently. The file passes this check if: (1) defined terms are either collected in a definitions section or clearly defined at first use; and (2) later occurrences of those terms use the same wording and meaning, without obvious contradictions or unexplained changes. The file fails this check if it relies on defined terms that are never defined, or if the same defined term is clearly used with conflicting meanings in different parts of the file.

name: Required notices and attachments actually present
description: Checks that when a file states that a notice, form, or schedule is attached or provided, it appears somewhere in the document set.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: whenever a file states that a specific notice, form, endorsement, schedule, or exhibit is 'attached', 'included with this policy', or 'provided with this filing', that item must actually appear somewhere in the attached files. The filing passes this check only if every such referenced item can be matched either to a section in the same file or to a separate attached file whose title or form number obviously matches the reference. If any promised or 'attached' item cannot be found anywhere in the document set, treat this check as failed and identify which reference is missing.

name: Signature and execution blocks where required
description: Checks that documents requiring signatures provide clear signature, date, and identification lines.
prompt: You are reviewing only the attached files in a new jersey serff filing. Ignore the serff-generated filing summary and general information tabs. Requirement: any document that requires a signature (for example applications, selection/rejection forms, acknowledgments, certifications, or officer attestations) must include clear signature and dating areas. The file passes this check if, whenever the text says that someone must sign, attest, or certify, the document provides: (1) at least one signature line labeled for the person signing (for example 'insured signature', 'officer signature'); and (2) an area to record the date of signature, and when appropriate, printed name and title. If the text requires a signature or certification but there is no obvious place for the person to sign and date, the file fails this check. If a document contains no language requiring a signature at all, this check is not applicable for that document.
